Problem:
Consider a complex valued function \\( z(t) \\) governed by the differential equation \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\), with \\( \\omega \\) being a real constant. We analyze the effects of an integral transformation \\( T[z](t) = \\int_{0}^{t} e^{-i\\omega s}z(s) ds \\) on the solution.

Assuming an intervention using a new integral transformation \\( U[z](t) = \\int_{0}^{t} e^{i\\omega s}z(s) ds \\) is applied at a time \\( t_1 \\), will the observed \\( z(T) \\) for \\( t_1 < T \\) depend only on the original differential equation and not on the transformations \\( T \\) or \\( U \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with \\( U[z] \\) applies yet another transformation with distinct properties, impacting both the evolution of \\( z(t) \\) post-\\( t_1 \\) and the eventual state at \\( T \\). The result at \\( T \\) therefore reflects the combined influences of the original differential equation, \\( T[z] \\), and \\( U[z] \\), creating a dependency beyond just the original equation.
